summary: William H. Cross was an employee of the U.S. House of Representatives Select Committee on Assassinations (HSCA). He is mentioned in several payroll and certification reports spanning from October 1977 to November 1978. These documents list his name, position, and salary during that period. The documents indicate that he was a staff member of the HSCA during its investigation into the assassination of President John F. Kennedy.
significance: William H. Cross's significance lies in his employment with the HSCA, the committee tasked with reinvestigating the JFK assassination. While the documents do not specify his exact role within the committee, his presence on payroll and certification reports indicates he was a staff member involved in the HSCA's operations during a portion of its investigation.
